response.answer_text: Generally and for the most part, according to the National Alliance to End Homelessness and HUD, the lack of affordable decent/dignified housing has been the main reason why there is an increase in homelessness. People experiencing homelessness and poverty include children, the aging elderly, the disabled, and those who choose to be homeless (the lowest fraction of the population). Think about the more than half million people who were counted as homeless on the one night when volunteers go through a community to count people not living in shelters and the people who live in shelters (both sheltered and unsheltered are homeless). That count does not include the homeless who sleep in abandoned buildings or cars. Those who share a couch or a room with a friend on that Point-In-Time Count are not part of the count. Therefore, you can be correct if you say there are twice as many as half million people experiencing homelessness. Wherever the cost of housing is high, you can expect to see people living on the streets or in the nearby woods. The City of Los Angeles and the City of Honolulu have mutual problems that makes their homelessness count greater than the rest of the country. The mutual problem is: High Area Median Rent. In fact, latest research shows that minimum wage earners can only afford $500 per month or less in rent. Do you know where decent and dignified one-bedrooms can be rented for $500 per month including utilities? That is a fact realized by nearly every community in the United States. The next thing to think about is: Disasters. What do you suppose happens when a town is flooded or destroyed by fire? Fact is that in Chico, California, there were 40,000 displaced without a place to live because of the devastating wildfire in 2018. They are homeless, living in motels or shelters or camping. While we have facts that point to the serious lack of affordable housing, partly because older housing is deteriorating and are not being rehabilitated, land owners and developers and real estate brokers can charge as much rent as they want. High story buildings are very expensive and more costly than building single family small houses. I’m against tiny houses because they are not made to last for a lifetime. I am for creative permanent essential houses that have bathrooms, good insulation, modern kitchen, living room and a spacious bedroom or two. It is what we’ve designed for our development that we hope some day will be built in a village setting. Research shows that people do not like living in high rises, because there are too many people converged into the same space. In rural communities, the environment is cleaner because the population is lower than in cities. However, developers are not building for affordability. They are building for profit. It will take the political will to allow modifications to zoning and restrictions on land. In our region of southwestern Colorado, we have a serious problem with water. Drought has lowered the amount of water washed down after a dry winter with very little snowmelt. While there are many ranches and farms up for sale, their water source is scarce, and it costs millions of dollars to connect to City water and to dig deeper wells. At the same time, waste management is a huge problem for a development. Regulations and laws that restrict properties to be used for affordable housing is compounded by the Not-In-My-Back-Yard (NIMBY) attitudes. Unless civic leaders look at the housing problems differently, we may as well sit back and watch more homeless campsites popping up everywhere they should not be. One researcher says that in order to end homelessness, every State of the nation needs to build 150,000 units of housing in an overnight — and, every one of those units must be dedicated to the homeless. Wages are not increasing, and minimum wage is not the same as “living wage” or “housing wage”. This is a worldwide problem. But, America needs to realize there is a drastic shift of wealth since President Trump and the Republicans gave tax breaks to the largest corporations — the ones who don’t increase minimum wages — and the top 1% of the wealthy. The big question may be (in my humble opinion): When will a revolution take place by the growing population of the poor and the homeless? History says it will happen — but, when? We are as a nation on a brink of recession since the most recent drop in the stock market only a few days ago. Trump is threatened by the forecast of a bad economy. He is “only worried about being re-elected”. He has divided this country so deeply that this nation is vulnerable to economic disaster!! We could have another crash of the market. Trump has destroyed our relationships with countries that were our Allies. When America falls, our enemies will have the capacity to destroy us from within. That whole scenario is my greatest concern!! If you don’t like homelessness populations now, wait until the next recession happens; you can expect more people losing homes and jobs. But there is hope! My hope is in the Lord God coming back to rule this earth. He is the only hope!

Major reasons for homelessness include:  Poor social and familial relationships - If you have very poor or non-existent relationships with your family then you have no one to provide you housing or loans to get you on your feet in troubled times. If you don't  have a partner or an SO, then you can also end up being homeless.Mental illness - If you are a mentally ill person who has an illness that is "treatable" on an outpatient basis, then you are likely to become homeless when/if you have personal or financial setbacks.Substance use/abuse - If you frequently overindulge in alcohol & illegal substances, unless you can also maintain employment, there's a strong likelihood that you will become homeless.Poor planning - You see this a great deal in "boomtowns". People frequently move to areas that they are unfamiliar with or simply know nothing about and expect to gain employment immediately. When this doesn't occur or when their employment has issues, they simply haven't planned for this, they haven't saved for this and as such end up being homeless.Lack of flexibility - Homeless people are often very inflexible. They want or need conditions to be in manners that are acceptable to them and will actually move out of situations (and back into homelessness) for reasons that could be altered by having a simple discussion or by compromising. There are many agencies willing to help people; but to do so they have to be flexible.While there are many more reasons that people become homeless, at least one or more of the above are root causes of their continued homelessness.

My rent went up until it was literally more than my average monthly wages. I had seen it coming and started looking for somewhere else to live, but there was a larger problem looming. You know how you’ve always heard you should only pay 25% to 30% of your wages on housing? Well, in California that translates to “you must prove that you make three to four times the rent to ‘qualify’ to rent this apartment”. The average rent for a modest one bedroom in Los Angeles is $2,200 per month. If you don’t make *at least* $6,600 per month, you can’t move in. San Francisco is even more hideously expensive. Sacramento, which I just visited for a week, is sitting right at about $1,200/month out in the suburbs. Do you make enough to not be homeless in California? Or will you rent half a bedroom with a total stranger for $700/month? That’s reality here. HOW everyone ends up on the streets for the first time varies greatly. It can be anything from loss of a supporting partner or family member, loss of their good health, loss of a job, loss of a lot of things to just straight up being priced out of the only home they’ve ever had and simply not ‘qualifying’ for any other housing, which is precisely what happened to me. What KEEPS people here homeless though is the very large difference between what they are paid and the cost of even entering housing. The systems put in place to help are so underfunded and overwhelmed that even after applying every single time the waiting list opened since the early 1990s, I’ve still not had my name drawn to be put on the waiting list for Section 8. I am far from alone in that. We need to break down the barriers to housing, provide more very low income housing and increase access to and the amount of housing subsidies if we want to solve the problem. Anything else is the equivalent of shoving everything under your bed and calling your bedroom ‘clean’. Let’s not do that. We’re adults now, we can surely figure out it works best for all involved if we just suck it up and deal with the problem the *correct* way instead of trying to hide it - can’t we? I hope so. There are a lot of very real people who need us all to get together and do that - and I just happen to be one of them. Again, I am far from alone in that.

One factor is the gap between the cost of living and the income of low-wage workers. In the 60's and 70's a year-round worker earning the minimum wage was paid enough to raise a family of three above the poverty line.  We didn't see much homelessness during this time because the cost of living was far less than what a minimum-wage worker would earn.  But starting from 1981, however, the minimum wage has only gone from $3.35/hr to $7.25/hr in 2007.  All the while, the cost of living has been increasing at a much faster rate.  The real value of minimum wage today is 26% less than in 1979[1].  As of 2009, a full-time minimum wage working year-round will earn a little more than $10,712/year this puts him nearly 40% below the poverty line[2]. Another is Job Security. In the previous decades, to the dismay of the workers, the US has faced a significant deterioration in job stability. The share of workers in "long term jobs" (those lasting more than 10 years) fell sharply between 1979 and 1996 [2].  There has been many cases where people have been forced on the streets due to involuntary job loss. A useful measure of the decline in job security is underemployment.  I think the NCH Fact Sheet[3] gives a pretty comprehensive summary of this: Unlike the unemployment rate, measure of underemployment reflect not only individuals who are unemployed, but also involuntary part-timers and those who want to work but have been discouraged by their lack of success.  In 2003 the underemployment rate stood at 10.1% , substantially higher than the 6.0% unemployment rate.  In 2006, it was somewhat lower at 8.4% but there is still a large gap between this rate and the unemployment rate which was 4.7% (The State of Working America, 2006).  One reason for the higher level of underemplyment is the increasing number of involuntary part-time workers--workers who want to work full time but have only been able to obtain part time work. You can see that for many Americans, work provides no escape from poverty.  The benefits of economic growth have not been equally distributed; instead, they've been concentrated at the top of income and wealth distributions. If you look at the lists of things that other writers have said cause a person to be homeless, you will see a pattern. Many of the causes (mental health issues, addiction, rigid thinking) are linked to stigma and social exclusion. I have always said homelessness=exclusion. I believe that any behaviour or circumstance which impacts your reputation leads you one step closer to homelessness. When behaviours that lead to exclusion outweigh those that create inclusion, the walls begin to fall down around you. Nobody simply becomes homeless. They lose a relationship(often for questionable behaviour), which makes them fall into depression, maybe they develop an addiction, which makes them late with their rent, which impacts their tenancy, etc. Notice that some of these qualities are circumstances, and some are choices. But it's not just behaviours that can cause you to be excluded. You may be LGBT, or a person of colour, or the “wrong” religion. My point is, whatever causes exclusion causes homelessness. Whatever causes inclusion ends homelessness. EXPANSION: I thought I was rather brief there, and I want to detail what I mean by inclusion being the only viable weapon against homelessness. Some examples of inclusion would be healthcare programs that “ask no questions,” or housing which opts not to run a credit check. Services which allow reconciliation policies, forgive past wrongs, these are all inclusive. If you look at inclusive programs, they create connections, and produce better results. The less you worry about the “rules,” and the more you understand relationships, the more effective you will be in this work.

10 Causes of Homelessness 1. ADDICTION Probably the most common stereotype of chronically homeless people is that they are drug and alcohol addicts — with good reason. 68% of U.S. cities report that addiction is a their single largest cause of homelessness.* “Housing First” initiatives are well intentioned, but can be short-sighted. A formerly homeless addict is likely to return to homelessness unless they deal with the addiction. Treatment programs are needed that treat the root causes of addiction and help men and women find a way back home. (*Source: National Coalition for the Homeless – Substance Abuse.) 2. DOMESTIC VIOLENCE Nationally, 50% of homeless women and children are fleeing domestic violence.* When a woman is abused, she faces a crisis of safety. If she stays in the home, she’ll be beaten again. If she leaves, she’ll have little means of support. Either choice is a tremendous risk. Choosing homelessness over abuse is both a brave and frightening decision. (*Source: National Coalition for the Homeless – Domestic Violence.) 3. MENTAL ILLNESS 6% of the American population suffers from mental illness. In the homeless population, that number jumps to 20-25%.* Serious mental illnesses disrupt people’s ability to carry out essential aspects of daily life, such as self care and household management. Without assistance, these men and women have little chance of gaining stability. (*Source: National Coalition for the Homeless – Mental Illness.) 4. JOB LOSS AND UNDEREMPLOYMENT The current downtown in the economy has many Americans barely getting by financially. Many are underemployed at wages that can’t sustain them. Layoffs and job cuts leave individuals and families in desperate circumstances. Unemployment benefits and savings run out, leaving people homeless who never thought it could happen to them. (See: National Coalition for the Homeless – Employment.) 5. FORECLOSURE Even people who have jobs are finding themselves upside down with their mortgages. From 2008 to 2009, foreclosures jumped by 32%. A 2009 survey estimates that as many as 10% of people seeking help from homeless organizations do so due to foreclosure.* (*Source: National Coalition for the Homeless – Foreclosure.) 6. POST-TRAUMATIC STRESS One any given night, as many as 200,000 military veterans sleep on the street.* The percentage of veterans with post-traumatic stress is growing among those returning from Iraq and Afghanistan. Adapting to “normal life” back in the U.S. is proving to be extremely difficult for the men and women who have served us. Unable to cope, some choose to leave homes, loved ones and jobs behind for homelessness and/or addiction. (*Source: National Coalition for the Homeless – Veterans.) 7. THROW AWAY TEENS Homeless teens often become so due to family conflicts. They’re kicked out or choose to run away over issues of drug/alcohol addiction, physical abuse, sexual orientation or teen pregnancy. Mental illness can play a significant role in teen homelessness just as it does in adults. Teens in foster care often end up on the street after they “age-out” of the system at age 18, a sad situation in which many feel alone or abandoned. 8. RELATIONAL BROKENNESS A homeless person is most often a deeply hurting person. By the time they come to a homelessness organization for help, they’ve burned through every supportive relationship possible. Friends and family are no longer able or willing to help, leaving the homeless man or woman very much alone. What relationships they have are usually predatory. In a sense, their situation is less about homelessness and more about unwantedness. A significant barrier to recovery often lies in the ability to restore trust and maintain healthy relationships. 9. GRIEF It’s not uncommon to discover that the men and women in many shelters are burdened by grief. Unable to deal with the death of a loved one or other significant trauma, they numb their pain in addiction. Addiction and apathy lead to the loss of job and home. They simply stop caring if they live or die. Grief becomes a roadblock to living. 10. DESPAIR “Once you get down this low, it’s hard to get back up,” we often hear homeless men and women say. The longer they are homeless, the more difficult it becomes to combat the lies they hear in their heads. They believe there’s no way out. They don’t deserve another chance. They’ll never break free from addiction. They’ll always be a failure. More than anything, these men and women need hope. Long term homeless persons almost always have one of three problems. And many of the long term homeless have two or three of these problems. Mental illness, alcoholism and drug addiction are largely responsible for long term homelessness. And solving the homeless problem is largely the problem of solving those three problems. The next biggest problem among the long term homeless are those who aren't mentally ill, but who have found the regular working life too difficult to deal with and who have opted to drop out. And I have known graduates from ever major university who fit under this category. And if you meet them, you would never know they are homeless. The old time traditional hobo would also fit into this category. Lastly, there are those who have usually been homeless for under a year who lost a job or who were divorced and who commonly but not always, have few job skills. They also tend to be younger or older, are often women who suddenly found themselves abandoned or unemployed. They usually find themselves on the streets due to the ending of a relationship (including kids leaving their homes for a variety of reasons) and the ending of relationships is the leading cause in the increasing number of women who are homeless. And the decline in the number of children families are having, leaves many women with no other place to go. The only good news for this last group is, assuming these newly homeless do not develop any of the other problems, they are usually off the streets in less than a year.

The conservative viewpoint is that homelessness is the direct result of one’s own actions, and continued homelessness is the direct result of one’s own inaction. The progressive viewpoint is that homelessness may not be the result of one’s own actions, and continued homelessness is the direct result of systematic oppression. To some degrees, both viewpoints are correct - some people have become homeless because they made stupid decisions, while some people have become homeless because of situations or accidents happening that are not their fault. On the same token, continued homelessness may indeed be a person’s own inaction, but it is extremely difficult to find a job as a homeless person - think about all of the hoops you have to jump through just to apply for a job. You need an address for filing taxes - which a homeless person won’t have. You need your social security number, which I can guarantee most people don’t even have memorized, much less homeless people having their cards on them. Etc. It’s difficult to say if there is a solution to the problem because it involves people, and people are complex. There’s no one correct image of all homeless people, and subsequently there cannot be a single correct solution to the problem. And anyone who’s quick to either dismiss all homeless people or support all homeless people has a very narrow-minded view of a complex problem.

There are long-term risk factors and short-term triggers. A long-term risk factor can be an illness, a lack of financial reserves, a lack of family support, a serious mortgage, a job where you are expendable, an addiction or tendency to get addicted easily,… It often takes a combination of these risk factors to be at serious risk for homelessness. A short-term trigger can be any sort of setback that pushes into these long-term risk factors. The loss of your job, combined with a hefty mortgage, could be enough if you don’t have any financial reserves to cover your living expenses while you find new employment. If you then have a lack of family support, you’re homeless, at least temporarily. Preventing homelessness is about reducing the long-term risk factors where possible. Ideally, save up enough money so that you can cover 6 months of unemployment. Maintain ties to your family if at all possible and healthy. Find employment where you’re not easily expandable. Have a backup option in case you lose your house, for whatever reason. If you have a vehicle that you could sleep in, that’s a major asset when you’re temporarily homeless. To put it differently, there are barriers to homelessness. When these barriers break down and then you’re pushed down the edge, you’re homeless. Try to keep up as many of these barriers as possible.

Homeless shelters are not truly “public accommodations.” Youth hostels are, but there are “catches:” they are intended for travelers, impose time limits (typically two weeks per year, or less) and generally do not accept guests who cannot prove that they reside outside the area. By contrast, hostels are quite common in Europe and generally cost no more than $20 / night - or less. I’ve seen a post on Quora where the writer expressed astonishment about how cheaply one can live “as a tourist” in France. Hostels are generally operated as for-profit businesses, but not always: some appear to operate as virtual charities. Suffice to say that not all hostel guests are young tourists: among the people I’ve met are itinerant workers, buskers, and retired people who do not travel. In some countries, hostels accept volunteers who receive “free” accommodations (and sometimes meals) in exchange for “housekeeping” work. Also suffice to say that hostel staff deals swiftly with disruptive or threatening conduct.
